div.l: Alas oure wardeyn̄ hase his palfrey lorn̄
This Aleyn̄ forgat both mele and corn̄
And was al out of mynde his husbondry
What whilk way is he gane he gan to crye
The wep wif cam leping outward at a ren̄
She seid alas he goth into the fenne
With wilde maris as fast as he can go
Vnthank come on his hand þat band him so
And he that bette shuld haue knytte þe Reyn̄
Alas coth Iohn / Aleyn for cristis peyn̄
Ley doun thy swerd and I wil myn̄ also
I is ful swift god wate as a Roo
Be goddis saule he mon̄ noȝt escape us bathe
Why nad thou putte the capul in the lathe
Ilhail Aleyn in faith thou is a fonne
Thes celi clerkis han ful fast y ronne
Toward the fenne Aleyn and eke Iohn
And whan̄ the Milner saugh that they wer͗e gon̄
He half a busshel of her floure hath take
And bad his wif knede therof a cake
He seid I trou the clerkis were afferd
Yit can a Milner͗e make a clerkis berd
For al her art ye lat hem go her wey
Lo where they go lat the childirn̄ pley
They gete him not so lightly be my croun̄
Thees celi clerkis ranne up and doun̄
With kepe kepe stand stand ossa warderer͗e
Ga wightly now and I salle kepe him here
But shortly til it was veray nyght
Thei couth not theigh they did al her might
Their capul cacch til it til it he ran̄ awey so fast
Til in a diche they caught him at last
Wery and wete as a beste is in the reyn̄
Cometh celi Iohn and with him Aleyn̄
Alas coth Iohn that day was borne
Now ar we dryuen to hething ⁊and to scorn̄
Oure corn̄ is stole men wil us folis calle
Both the warden̄ and oure felawis alle
And namely the Milner welaweye
Thus pleyneth Iohn as he goth by þe wey
Toward the Milne and Bayard in his hand
The Milner sitting by the fire he fande
